docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the nation's future supply of research chimpanzees in jeopardy, Federal authorities plan to create a special population of 350 pampered animals that would be exempted from medical duties and enjoy emotionally rich upbringings designed to enhance their reproductive skills. Medical scientists consider chimpanzees, the closest relative to humans in the animal world, to be indispensable for certain experiments, including future tests of vaccines against AIDS. The projected decline in research animals has engendered wide concern. Since the mid-1970's, no imports have been permitted of chimpanzees caught in the wilds of Africa, where the species is threatened. Hundreds of the animals have been bred in captivity. But without new measures, scientists say, the future availability of chimpanzees will be endangered by two trends.

headline.main: WILL THERE BE ENOUGH CHIMPS FOR RESEARCH

docs.lead_paragraph: IN most Long Island waters, the scallop-harvesting season is only a month old, yet for baymen on the East End it is virtually over. They have discovered that approximately 90 percent of the scallop crop was destroyed by last summer's mysterious algae bloom. Of more far-reaching significance is the fact that the ''bugs,'' or baby scallops, also were destroyed, meaning that baymen will have no crop next fall. This may have disastrous consequences, particularly for East End baymen, many of whom depend on scalloping for much of their income. The scallop industry represented more than $1 million in business on the East End in 1984.

headline.main: OUTLOOK FOR SCALLOPS AND BAYMEN IS GLOOMY

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have identified groups of infants who run a higher-than-average risk of dying from sudden infant death syndrome, according to the initial results of a study by the National Institutes of Health. Dr. Charlotte S. Catz of the agency's National Institute for Child Health and Human Development told a joint hearing of three House committees this week that preliminary results of a nationwide study of 800 such cases indicated that factors including race, a mother who smokes and the mother's level of education could increase the likelihood that the baby will suffer the syndrome. The study is to be completed next year. The hearing was held by the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families and subcommittees of the Post Office and Civil Service Committee and the Energy and Commerce Committee.

headline.main: INFANT DEATH DATA INDICATE HIGH RISK GROUPS
